guide.title: Gnome 2.12 Upgrade Guide
guide.abstract: This guide shows you the recommended way of upgrading your existing to GNOME 2.12. It assumes that GNOME 2.12 is in unstable, and not in package.mask anymore.

chapter.title: Whats new ( on the Gentoo side )

body.p: Whats changed since 2.12_rc1:

ul.li: totem and librsvg use gecko-sdk with the 'nsplugin' useflag
evolution-exchange is not included in the GNOME meta anymore.
firefox use flag removed from evolution due to SSL breakage. ( will be added again later )

body.p: Whats changed since 2.10.2:

ul.li: mozilla is no longer a requirement for GNOME since epiphany can compile against firefox

body.p: First, start by adding all the necessary packages into your package.unmask file. If you are running unstable already, this is not necessary.
body.note:
An almost complete list of packages that you have to add is located at
package.keywords

body.p: Next, upgrade python to version 2.4.

body.warn: If you have gnome-doc-utils installed, re-emerge it. ( you should now have version >= version 0.4.1 )

body.impo: Want automounting USB sticks and other things to just work? See "So Now What?" in this guide.

body.p: This is the fun part :) Upgrade to GNOME 2.12.
Or, if you like not so heavy things:
Check if you need to run revdep-rebuild by doing:
You will know if you need to run it because some packages will be listed. To run it, just remove the "-p" flag.
Now, exit your current GNOME session, and restart it!

section.title: Want things to automatically automount when you plug them in?

body.p: First, add hal and dbus to your useflags by editing /etc/make.conf.
Next, make sure you have unmasked hal, dbus, pmount, and gamin. ( if you are running ~x86, this is not necessary! ) In order to use gamin, you must have an inotify enabled kernel.
The inotify option is located at "File systems -> Inotify file change notification support".
Below, please make sure to change x86 to your architecture. ( If its not x86 )
You most likely have cryptsetup installed, and its a blocker for crypsetup-luks, so do:
If you have an older version of hal installed, rm -rf /etc/hal/device.d . The hal ebuild will tell you to do this anyways, so lets just do it here first.
Also check to make sure you do not have app-admin/fam installed. If you do, follow the code listing below:
body.pre: # rc-update del famd # emerge unmerge fam
body.p: Next, update your machine so it recompiles things with the new useflags by using --newuse. One way to do this is emerge -uDav --newuse world
Now we need to start dbus and hal. They need to start up every time you restart your computer.
Don't forget to add yourself to the plugdev group in /etc/group.
Now you should be able to start gnome-volume-manager from the commandline and insert a USB stick, watch it automount and place an icon on your desktop :)

One way to have gnome-volume-manager run at login is to goto into the Preferences Menu -> Sessions. Then select the Startup Programs tab, and add gnome-volume-manager. If you want to change gnome-volume-manager's behavior, start gnome-volume-properties from the commandline.

section.title: What if its not one of the bugs listed above?

body.p: Please check the GNOME 2.12 Tracker bug here to see if theres a bug already filed for the same problem: http://bugs.gentoo.org/103197

Next, search bugzilla for the name of your package to see if someone has already filed a bug for it. If after searching for about 2 years ( just kidding ), you can't find a similar bug, please file a bug. ( see below )
If you want to know how to file a bug, please consult: http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/bugzilla-howto.xml
You can also find us in #gentoo-desktop
